Features: The PlantVillage dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating machine learning models, particularly deep learning models, for plant disease diagnosis. It contains 54,306 images of 14 crop species with 26 diseases or healthy states, enabling researchers to develop and test models for mobile disease diagnostics. Studies focus on classification accuracy, model performance, and feature extraction, often using techniques like CNNs, AlexNet, GoogLeNet, and SVMs. The dataset supports research in image-based plant health assessment, highlighting both advancements and limitations in machine learning approaches.

The IP102 dataset is primarily used for insect pest recognition and classification, featuring 164,700 images to train and evaluate models. It serves as a benchmark for large-scale insect pest recognition, supporting the development and evaluation of deep learning models, particularly in field crops. Researchers use it to enhance model performance, test real-time mobile device-based detection, and address limitations in smaller datasets, focusing on accuracy, efficiency, and the identification of 102 common crop pests.

ImageNet is used for pre-training deep learning models, which are then fine-tuned for plant disease diagnosis, including pumpkin leaf disease classification. It provides a large-scale hierarchical image database, enhancing model performance through transfer learning. This approach improves accuracy and model performance on specific plant disease datasets like PlantVillage.

The PlantVillage Dataset is used to train and evaluate deep learning models for classifying healthy and diseased plants, particularly in cotton and other crops. It contains 220,592 labeled images across 271 disease categories, making it the largest available dataset for plant disease recognition. Researchers use it to assess model performance, robustness, and generalization capabilities, focusing on classification accuracy and the development of mobile disease diagnostics. The dataset's extensive size and variety of disease categories enable comprehensive testing and comparison of machine learning algorithms in agricultural image processing.

The PlantDoc dataset is used to train, test, and validate models for visual plant disease detection. It focuses on improving the accuracy, reliability, and robustness of disease recognition algorithms, particularly in identifying diseased leaves and classifying plant diseases in uncontrolled environments. The dataset covers 13 crops and 17 diseases, comprising 2,598 images, enabling researchers to develop and evaluate object detection models for plant health monitoring.

The CCDDB dataset is used for image augmentation in plant disease diagnosis, specifically by expanding the dataset through horizontal and vertical flipping. This enhances model training, improving the accuracy and robustness of machine learning models in diagnosing plant diseases. The dataset's ability to generate additional training images through augmentation is a key feature that enables more effective research in this area.

The FieldPlant dataset is used to train and evaluate deep learning models for plant disease detection and classification, specifically focusing on field plant images. This enhances model robustness and accuracy by providing diverse and realistic data. The dataset's field-specific images are crucial for improving the performance of disease detection models in real-world conditions.

The DS_corn dataset is used to evaluate optimization algorithms for accuracy in corn disease diagnosis, focusing on feature selection and classification performance. It is employed to assess the effectiveness of various algorithms in selecting relevant features and improving classification accuracy, contributing to the development of more efficient and accurate disease diagnostic systems.

The rice plant image dataset is used for validating the detection and classification of rice plant diseases through image-based diagnostics and machine learning approaches. Specifically, it supports the prediction of three rice diseases using a deep convolutional neural network, classifying healthy and diseased rice plant leaves. With over 4000 images, the dataset enables robust training and testing of models for disease classification.

The PlantVillage collection dataset is used to train and evaluate plant disease detection algorithms, specifically focusing on image-based classification. It includes over 3000 images of 14 plant species. Researchers employ this dataset to develop and test models like an improved YOLOv5 algorithm, aiming to enhance the accuracy of plant disease recognition.

The dataset of 14,956 images with 38 distinct classes is primarily used for training and evaluating models focused on plant disease diagnosis and leaf disease detection. Researchers employ various methodologies, including feature extraction and image processing techniques, deep learning architectures like VGGNet and AlexNet, and machine learning algorithms such as Random Forest and SVM. The dataset supports research on improving the accuracy and performance of classification models, particularly in the context of plant health monitoring and disease identification.

The PVD dataset is used for evaluating and training machine learning models, specifically CNNs, for diagnosing plant diseases through image analysis. It contains 87,867 photos and has been utilized to test spatially pyramid-oriented and eight-layered CNN methods, achieving high accuracy rates, particularly in diagnosing tomato diseases. The dataset's large size and focus on image-based detection enable robust model training and evaluation.

The '54306 leaf images' dataset is used to train and evaluate Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models for plant disease detection. It focuses on 14 crops and 26 classes, including healthy leaves. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test algorithms that can accurately identify various plant diseases, enhancing agricultural monitoring and management.

The PlantCLEF dataset is used for classifying plant species, specifically in the PlantCLEF 2015 challenge, where deep convolutional neural networks were employed to classify 1,000 plant species. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test advanced machine learning models for plant identification, contributing to biodiversity research and ecological studies.

The Cassava Leaf Disease Classification dataset is primarily used to train and evaluate machine learning models for recognizing and diagnosing plant diseases. It focuses on visual symptoms in various plant parts, particularly cassava leaves, but also includes diseases affecting other plant species like mango. The dataset enables researchers to develop and test models that can accurately identify a wide range of plant diseases, enhancing disease management and crop health monitoring.

The Multi-class pest dataset 2018 (MPD2018) is used for multi-class pest detection and classification, specifically to identify similar pests across different categories. Researchers employ a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model to analyze the dataset, enabling accurate classification of pests. This approach addresses the challenge of distinguishing between visually similar pests, enhancing the precision of pest management strategies.

The Sugar beet leaf images dataset is used to train and evaluate deep learning models, specifically Faster R-CNN and CNN, for detecting and classifying sugar beet leaf diseases and pests. Research focuses on improving disease detection accuracy and addressing challenges in distinguishing similar pests. Image augmentation techniques are applied to enhance model robustness.

The 'Citrus 199 Leaves' dataset is used for symptom-based automated detection of citrus diseases. Researchers apply color histogram and textural descriptors in conjunction with machine learning algorithms to achieve high sensitivity in disease identification. This dataset enables the development and validation of models that can accurately diagnose citrus diseases, enhancing early detection and management strategies.

The NLB dataset for maize plant is primarily used to train and evaluate machine learning models for detecting Northern Leaf Blight in maize plants. This dataset supports research in plant disease diagnosis across multiple species, enhancing the robustness and applicability of image-based classification methods.

Name (extracted): Winter wheat Powdery mildew Hyperspectral reflectance
Features: The Winter wheat Powdery mildew Hyperspectral reflectance dataset is used to detect powdery mildew in winter wheat through leaf-level hyperspectral measurements. This dataset facilitates the development and validation of models for early and accurate identification of powdery mildew, enhancing disease management strategies.

The LifeCLEF 2015 dataset is used to evaluate factors affecting the performance of deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) in plant identification tasks. The dataset of 7046 images is used to train and evaluate deep learning models, specifically YOLO v3, R, and v5, for identifying insect pests. It achieves accuracies ranging from 74.6% to 79.8%. The Tomato Late Blight dataset is used to train and validate neural network models for diagnosing tomato late blight disease.
